results.title: The Mansion [game trailer]
results.brief_description: It’s a moonless night… Let’s go explore a mansion. In ‘The Mansion’, a nameless character finds himself with the task of searching an old mansion. Although he can’t understand the lost children it doesn’t take a true connection to know only he can help. The story is told through a platformer format, inspired by games such as Super Mario Bros.

results.title: Voyager [game trailer]
results.brief_description: In a faraway world lived two clans, Dezminus and Akai. Their only connection was a trade route, trading Dezminus’ ores for Akai’s wheat. But one day Dezminus’s food supplies stopped coming. So Dezminus decided to declare war and conquer the Clan of Akai. So they sent a warship to declare war on Akai. The captain of that vessel was…you.

results.title: My City Walkabout
results.creator_credit: Emmie Seaton, Mateuse Pingol and MatEm Productions
results.brief_description: ‘My City Walkabout’ is a film with a French New Wave aesthetic that follows an Aboriginal man searching for his place in modern Australian society. Set in the man’s dream, the film explores magic realism sequences to illustrate the protagonist’s desire to alter his reality and ultimately find his identity.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Emmie Seaton, Mateuse Pingol and MatEm Productions

results.title: Max's Farm
results.brief_description: Max is a perfectionist. He loves his farm and wants it to be the best. The ‘Farmer’s Weekly’ arrives and his farm rates 27th. That’s a great score, but Max wants it number 1. He tries to improve his farm by eliminating what he thinks are pests, but that just makes his farm worse. He has to find out how to get things work together.

results.title: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
ACMI’s ‘Australian Perspectives’ film season frames contemporary Australian filmmaking against a backdrop of archival classics and special guest presentations.
This question and answer session with a panel of Australian film industry figures, was held on Saturday 7th September 2013 as Part 2 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’, following a screening of Nigel Buesst’s 1971 film ‘Bonjour Balwyn’.
Hosted by Rochelle Siemienowicz, the panel included Nigel Buesst, Peter Hourigan, Alan Finney and John Flaus.
The discussion highlights the key role of Melbourne, and Carlton in particular, as a centre for independent filmmaking in the 1960s and 1970s. The memories and anecdotes recounted by the panellists illustrate the vibrancy and creative energy of the Melbourne scene and the socio-economic context that allowed it to flourish.
NOTE: Part 1 of the ‘Australian Perspectives’ season ‘Carlton New Wave’ was an August 2013 screening of Brian Davies’ 1966 film ‘Pudding Thieves’.
results.title_for_label: Carlton New Wave: Question and Answer Session
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Kenneally, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI

results.title: Spectacle Director Showcase: Paul Goldman
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, Kim Montgomery, Shelley Matulick and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Acclaimed Australian filmmaker Paul Goldman has directed over 200 music videos including work for Elvis Costello, INXS, Kylie Minogue, Crowded House and Silverchair. Paul also directed seminal Australian films like ‘Australian Rules’ and ‘Suburban Mayhem’. In this inverview, Paul talks candidly about his early music videos for Nick Cave’s ‘The Birthday Party’ and ‘The Reels’.

Created as part of “Spectacle : The Music Video Exhibition” 26 September 2013 - 23 February 2014. ACMI Digital Programs worked with Exhibitions to interview five Australian directors featured in the exhibition about the art and techniques of music video production.

results.title: The Lost Thing
results.creator_credit: Andrew Ruhemann, Shaun Tan, Leo Baker, Sophie Byrne and Passion Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, this Oscar Award winning animated short film of Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’, tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeonholes.
